speaker: Doctor
text: So you're here about a breast mass. Can you tell me when you first noticed it?

speaker: Patient
text: It was about 4 weeks ago, I remember it was during a shower, I felt something new and it was a bit hard.

speaker: Doctor
text: About a month ago, I was doing a self-exam and I felt this lump. At first, I thought it was just a cyst or something, but it's been there ever since.

speaker: Patient
text: Since then, it's gotten a lot bigger, to be honest. I can feel it more easily when I'm getting dressed or when I'm in certain positions.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any changes in the lump since you first felt it, such as it getting bigger or more painful?

speaker: Patient
text: It's definitely gotten bigger, I can feel it's more prominent now. Sometimes I feel like it's pushing against my skin.

speaker: Doctor
text: No, it's remained the same size, but I have noticed that it's gotten a bit more tender to the touch. Can you tell me a bit about your family history, have any of your relatives had breast cancer?

speaker: Patient
text: No, my family history is pretty clean. My mother and sisters are all fine, and I don't think anyone in my family has ever had breast cancer.

speaker: Doctor
text: Do you have a history of any other breast conditions, such as fibrocystic changes or a previous biopsy?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I've never had any issues with my breasts before, nothing like this has ever happened to me. I'm usually very diligent about my self-exams and I've never noticed anything like this lump before.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see.  So, you're saying the lump hasn't changed in size but has become more tender to the touch. Have you had any recent trauma to the breast area that might have caused this tenderness?

speaker: Patient
text: No, nothing like that. I haven't had any accidents or falls that would have caused an injury to my breast.

speaker: Doctor
text: No, I haven't had any recent trauma to the breast area. I'm a bit concerned about the tenderness, though. Can you tell me if you've experienced any nipple discharge or changes in the nipple's appearance?

speaker: Patient
text: No, my nipple looks the same as always. I haven't noticed any discharge or changes in its color or shape.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your menstrual cycle or any symptoms related to your menstrual period that might be contributing to the tenderness?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, my menstrual cycle has been pretty normal lately, no changes in duration or heaviness. But to be honest, I haven't had my period yet this month, which is unusual for me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any previous mammograms or breast ultrasounds that might show a history of breast changes or abnormalities?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. I've always been pretty healthy and haven't had any reason to get a mammogram or ultrasound before.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see. So, you haven't had any previous mammograms or breast ultrasounds that might show a history of breast changes or abnormalities. Can you tell me if you've had any previous biopsies or surgeries in the breast area?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I've never had any biopsies or surgeries in my breast area before. I've always been pretty healthy, like I said.

speaker: Doctor
text: You haven't had any previous biopsies or surgeries in the breast area. Have you experienced any weight loss or fatigue that could be related to the lump?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't experienced any weight loss or fatigue. I've actually been feeling pretty normal, just a bit concerned about the lump.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any previous history of breast cancer in your family, such as a mother or sister who's been diagnosed?

speaker: Patient
text: No, my family history is pretty clean, like I said before. My mother and sisters are all fine.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your family history and the fact that you haven't had any previous biopsies or surgeries in the breast area. Have you ever used hormonal birth control or experienced any significant hormonal changes in your life?

speaker: Patient
text: I did use hormonal birth control in the past, for about 10 years, but I stopped about 5 years ago. And yes, I did experience some significant hormonal changes when I stopped taking the birth control pills, my periods got a bit irregular for a while.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to perform a breast exam to get a better sense of the lump's texture and location. Can you please lie down and put your arm behind your head for me?

speaker: Patient
text: I'm a bit nervous about this, but okay, I'll try to relax. What are you looking for exactly?

speaker: Doctor
text: Let's take a look at the lump. Can you tell me if it's located near the nipple or in a more peripheral area of the breast?

speaker: Patient
text: It's in the outer part of my breast, I'd say it's about an inch away from the nipple. I can feel it more easily when I'm in certain positions, like when I'm leaning forward or lying down.

speaker: Doctor
text: The lump is located about an inch below the nipple, in a more central area of the breast. That's helpful to know. Have you experienced any difficulty with breastfeeding in the past, or any issues with milk production?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I've never had any issues with breastfeeding. I've been teaching elementary school for years, and I've never had any children, so I've never had to breastfeed.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine the lump more closely. Can you please show me exactly where it is and how it feels?

speaker: Patient
text:
It's right here, on the outer part of my breast, I'll show you. *points to the lump* 

It's hard to the touch, and it's a bit bigger than I'd like it to be. 

I can feel it more easily when I'm in certain positions, like when I'm leaning forward or lying down. 

It's not really tender to the touch, but it's a bit uncomfortable when I press on it.

speaker: Doctor
text: The lump is about an inch below the nipple, and it's more tender to the touch, but hasn't changed in size. Can you describe the texture of the lump to me, is it smooth or irregular?

speaker: Patient
text: It's kind of... bumpy, I guess. I've noticed that when I press on it, the edges can feel a bit uneven.

speaker: Doctor
text: The lump is located about an inch below the nipple, in a central area of the breast, and it's tender to the touch but hasn't changed in size. Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your skin, such as redness or dimpling around the lump?

speaker: Patient
text: No, my skin looks the same as always, no redness or dimpling around the lump. It's actually just a bit firmer than the surrounding tissue.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Based on your symptoms and physical examination, I have to consider the possibility of breast cancer. 

However, I would like to request some test results to confirm our suspicions. REQUEST TEST: Mammogram.
